importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on Monday, October 20, 2025, and marks the culmination of the ALCS between the Blue Jays and Mariners, setting the stage for the World Series matchup.
Game 1 of the World Series is scheduled for Friday, October 24, 2025, in Toronto, marking the official start of the championship series.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The article references Toronto's dramatic rise in performance from a last-place finish in 2024 to a 94-68 record in 2025, culminating in their ALCS victory by July through October.
The Dodgers' postseason run, including the NLDS and NLCS victories, took place during late 2025, especially in September and October, with key performances in September and October games.

keyTakeAways: The Toronto Blue Jays earned their first World Series berth in over 30 years by defeating the Seattle Mariners 4-3 in Game 7 of the ALCS, marking a significant turnaround from their 2024 performance.
The Los Angeles Dodgers, with the largest payroll in MLB, are the favored team in the World Series, having won two championships in recent years and dominating the NL playoffs.

Shohei Ohtani delivered a historic performance in Game 4 of the NLCS, recording three home runs as a batter and a 6.1-inning shutout as a pitcher, making it one of the most dominant individual games in MLB history.
The Blue Jays' offensive strength, especially in high-scoring games against the Yankees in the ALDS, proved crucial, though they required seven grueling games to overcome the Mariners.
Despite the Dodgers' overall dominance, their bullpen struggled during the regular season, creating a potential vulnerability the Blue Jays could exploit in the World Series.
The World Series will begin on October 24, 2025, with Game 1 in Toronto, marking a pivotal moment in MLB's postseason history.

namedEntities.name: Toronto Blue Jays
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Major League Baseball team based in Toronto, Canada.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Blue Jays are the subject of the article's central narrative — they won the American League Championship Series and are now set to face the Dodgers in the World Series, marking their first trip to the final since 1993.

namedEntities.name: Los Angeles Dodgers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Major League Baseball team based in Los Angeles, California.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Dodgers are the opposing team in the World Series, having dominated the NL postseason and boasting the largest payroll, making them a top-tier and formidable challenge to the Blue Jays.

namedEntities.name: Seattle Mariners
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Major League Baseball team based in Seattle, Washington.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Mariners were the Blue Jays' opponent in the ALCS, and their early lead and eventual collapse in Game 7 set the stage for the Blue Jays' victory and their return to the World Series.

namedEntities.name: Shohei Ohtani
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A two-way superstar player for the Los Angeles Dodgers, known for excelling as both a pitcher and a hitter.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ohtani delivered a legendary performance in Game 4 of the NLCS with three home runs and a 6.1-inning shutout, which became a centerpiece of the Dodgers' postseason success.

namedEntities.name: Jeff Hoffman
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A pitcher for the Toronto Blue Jays, who played a key role in the ALCS victory.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hoffman provided commentary after the Blue Jays' ALCS win, emphasizing team resilience and the importance of staying close under pressure.

namedEntities.name: American League Championship Series
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The playoff series that determines the American League representative for the World Series.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Blue Jays' 4-3 victory in the ALCS over the Mariners was the decisive event that qualified them for the World Series.

namedEntities.name: National League Championship Series
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The playoff series that determines the National League representative for the World Series.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Dodgers' sweep of the Brewers in the NLCS highlighted their postseason dominance and prepared them for the World Series matchup.

namedEntities.name: World Series
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The championship series between the American League and National League champions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Blue Jays and Dodgers are set to face off in the World Series, marking a high-stakes showdown between two top-tier franchises with contrasting playoff paths.

namedEntities.name: George Springer
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A key offensive player for the Toronto Blue Jays.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Springer hit a late three-run home run in Game 7 of the ALCS that ended the Mariners' hopes, turning the tide of the series.

namedEntities.name: Philadelphia Phillies
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Major League Baseball team that lost to the Dodgers in the NLDS.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Their single win over the Dodgers in the NLDS illustrates the Dodgers' strength in postseason play, despite a regular-season record of 96-66.

namedEntities.name: Milwaukee Brewers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Major League Baseball team that lost to the Dodgers in the NLCS.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Brewers' two-earned-run performance in four games against the Dodgers underscores the Dodgers' pitching dominance in the NLCS.

namedEntities.name: Pittsburgh Pirates
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Major League Baseball team that lost to the Dodgers in the regular season.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Pirates' September sweep of the Dodgers highlights the Dodgers' regular-season instability, particularly in late-game bullpen performance.

namedEntities.name: Fox Sports
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A media network that aired a post-game interview with Jeff Hoffman.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The interview with Hoffman on Fox provided direct commentary on the Blue Jays' resilience and strategy during the ALCS.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Toronto Blue Jays, after a dramatic 4-3 victory in Game 7 of the ALCS over the Seattle Mariners, have earned their first World Series berth in over 30 years, marking a major turnaround from their 2024 collapse. The Blue Jays, who outscored the Yankees 34-0 in the ALDS, overcame a strong Mariners lead in the ALCS thanks to a late-game home run by George Springer. Meanwhile, the Los Angeles Dodgers, with the largest payroll and two World Series titles in recent years, have dominated the postseason, including sweeping the Milwaukee Brewers in the NLCS and showcasing a historic performance by Shohei Ohtani. The Dodgers are now set to face the Blue Jays in the World Series, beginning on October 24 in Toronto. While the Blue Jays’ offensive prowess and resilience are key strengths, the Dodgers’ bullpen remains a vulnerability that could be exploited. This matchup represents a historic convergence of two top-tier franchises, with significant implications for the future of MLB postseason dynamics.
title: Dodgers and Blue Jays Face Off in World Series After ALCS Victory
